Ye dazz'ling lamps, ye jocund fires,</br>That from yon fabric shine,</br>Where grateful pleasure yet admires</br>Her Lacy's great design:</br>And ye, who from the fields which lie</br>Round Chelsea, with amazement's eye,</br>The gardens, and the dome survey,</br>Whose walks, whose trees, whose lights among,</br>Wander the courtly train along</br>Their thought-dispelling way.

Ah, splendid room!  ah, pleasing shade!</br>Ah, walks belov'd in vain!</br>Where oft in happier times I stray'd,</br>A stranger then to pain:</br>I feel the gales, which from you blow</br>A momentary bliss bestow,</br>As waving fresh their gladsome wing,</br>They seem to sooth my famish'd soul,</br>And redolent of tea, and roll,</br>To breathe a second spring.

Rotonda, say, for thou hast seen</br>Full many a sprightly race,</br>In thy bright round with step serene,</br>The paths of pleasure trace;</br>Who chiefly now delight to lave</br>Green Hyson in the boiling wave,</br>The sable Coffee which distill?</br>What lounging progeny are found,</br>Who stroll incessant round, and round,</br>Like horses in a mill?

While some on earnest business dream,</br>And gravely stupid try</br>To search each complicated scheme</br>Of public policy:</br>Some ladies leave the spacious dome,</br>Around the garden's maze to roam,</br>And unknown regions dare descry;</br>Still as they walk they look behind,</br>Lest fame, a secret foe, should find</br>From some malicious eye.

Loud mirth is theirs, and pleasing praise,</br>To beauty's shrine address'd;</br>The sprightly songs, the melting lays,</br>Which charm the soften'd breast;</br>Theirs lively wit, invention free,</br>The sharp bon mot, keen repartee,</br>And every art coquets employ,</br>The thoughtless day, the jocund night,</br>The spirits brisk, the sorrows light,</br>That fly th' approach of day.

Alas!  regardless of their doom,</br>The lovely victims rove;</br>No sense of suff'rings yet to come</br>Can now their prudence move:</br>But see where all around them wait!</br>The ministers of female fate,</br>An artful, perjur'd, cruel train;</br>Ah! shew them where in ambush stand,</br>To seize their prey, the faithless band,</br>Of false deceitful men!

These shall the lust of gaming wear,</br>That harpy of the mind,</br>With all the troop of rage and fear,</br>That follows close behind:</br>Or pining love shall waste their youth,</br>Or jealousy with rankling tooth</br>That gnaws bright Hymen's golden chain,</br>Who opens wide the fatal gate,</br>For sad distrust, and ruthless hate,</br>And Sorrow's pallid train.

Ambition this shall tempt to fix</br>Her hopes on something high,</br>To barter for a coach and six</br>Her peace and liberty.</br>The stings of Scandal these shall try,</br>And Affectation's haughty eye</br>That scowls on those it us'd to greet,</br>The cutting sneer, th' abusive song,</br>And false report that glides along</br>With never-resting feet.

And lo!  where in the vale of years</br>A grizly tribe are seen;</br>Fancy's pale family of fears,</br>More hideous than their Queen:</br>Struck with th' imaginary crew,</br>Which artless Nature never knew,</br>These aid from quacks, and cordials beg,</br>While this transform'd by folly's hand,</br>Remains a while at her command,</br>A tea-pot, or an egg.

To each her suff'rings, all must grieve,</br>And pour a silent groan;</br>At homage others charms receive,</br>Or slights that meet their own:—</br>But ill the voice of truth severe,</br>Will suit the gay regardless ear</br>Whose joy in mirth, and revels lies;</br>Thought would destroy this paradise,</br>No more! — Where ignorance is bliss,</br>'Tis folly to be wise.</br>
